questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain and dizziness with a history of amenorrhea for the past 8 weeks. On examination, she is pale, diaphoretic, and hypotensive with a blood pressure of 80/50 mmHg and a heart rate of 120 bpm. An ultrasound confirms a ruptured ectopic pregnancy with significant intra-abdominal bleeding. The patient is in shock and requires immediate surgical intervention. Which of the following surgical procedures is most appropriate for this patient?

A 30-year-old woman presents with fever, offensive vaginal discharge, and lower abdominal pain following a spontaneous abortion at 18 weeks of gestation. On examination, she has uterine tenderness. Ultrasound shows no evidence of spread beyond the uterus. What is the most likely clinical grade of her septic abortion?
questions.explanation:
Grade

Description

Management

I

(Option A)

Localized infection in the uterus

Hospitalization, Antibiotics, Uterine evacuation post-antibiotics if indicated

II

(Option B)

The infection spreads beyond the uterus (parametrium, tubes, ovaries)

Broad-spectrum antibiotics, Analgesics, Anti-tetanus serum, Clinical monitoring, Delayed evacuation

III

(Option C)

Generalized peritonitis or shock, often from illegal abortions

Intensive antibiotics, Supportive therapy, Emergency surgery if needed

Preferred Regimen

Alternatives
  • Piperacillin-tazobactam (4.5 g IV q8h)
  • Plus vancomycin based on culture resistance patterns
  • Imipenem (500 mg IV q6h)
  • Gentamicin (5 mg/kg/day IV) + Ampicillin (2 g IV q4h) + Clindamycin (900 mg IV q8h)
  • Levofloxacin (500 mg IV daily) + Metronidazole (500 mg IV q8h)

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency room at 8 weeks of gestation with heavy vaginal bleeding accompanied by severe cramping. On examination, the cervix is found to be partially dilated and ultrasound shows the presence of products of conception. Which type of spontaneous abortion is described here?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Clinical Presentation

USG Finding

Management

Threatened Abortion

(option A)

Vaginal bleeding during the first 20 weeks of pregnancy while the embryo or fetus is still alive and the cervical os remains closed.

Vaginal bleeding: spotting to heavy flow

Symptoms: suprapubic discomfort, mild cramps, pelvic pressure

TVS: Detects viable intrauterine pregnancy.

Fetal cardiac activity (by 6-6.5 weeks), subchorionic hematoma (may be present).

Expectant management: Monitor symptoms, acetaminophen for pain relief, avoid sexual intercourse. Progesterone supplementation is not recommended.

Incomplete Abortion

(Option B)

The cervix begins to open.

Incompletely expelled products of conception.

Heavier vaginal bleeding with cramping.

TVS: Retained products of conception in the uterus, and dilated cervix.

Surgical evacuation (curettage): High success rate (95-100%). - Expectant management: Higher failure rate (~25%). Medication (Misoprostol): Induces contractions, failure rate 5-30%.

Complete Abortion

(Option C)

All products of conception are expelled from the uterus and the cervix closes.

Bleeding subsides, and cramping decreases.

TVS: Thin endometrium, no gestational sac. Serial β-hCG is helpful if uncertain.

No further intervention is usually needed.

Anti D if Rh +ve.

Missed Abortion

(Option D)

Nonviable pregnancy, products of conception retained within the uterus, closed cervix.

Disappearance of pregnancy symptoms, light brown vaginal discharge.

TVS:

  • Absence of fetal cardiac activity (CRL ≥7mm), (or)
  • MSD ≥25mm without visible embryo, (or)
  • Lack of embryo growth post-yolk sac presence (11 days) or post-initial scan (2 weeks without yolk sac)

Similar to incomplete abortion.

Inevitable Abortion of a Previable Fetus

Cervical dilation with ruptured membranes (PPROM) or significant membrane ballooning, making continuation impossible.

Abundant watery vaginal discharge increases with coughing or the Valsalva manoeuvre.

Ultrasound: Confirms PPROM with decreased amniotic fluid or visualization of fluid between amnion and chorion.

First Trimester: Leads to uterine contractions or infection, necessitating termination. Second Trimester (Previable):

  • Bleeding or Fever: Immediate uterine evacuation.
  • No Bleeding or Fever: Expectant management with close monitoring, antibiotics if needed.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a 12-day history of a missed period and a positive pregnancy test undergoes a procedure to empty her uterus. Identify the instrument used in this early pregnancy management procedure:
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
(Option B)

Menstrual Regulation (Option D)

Use

Uterine evacuation up to 12 weeks of pregnancy for medical termination.

Aspiration of endometrial cavity within 14 days of missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle.

Instrument used

MVA Syringe: Has double pinchable valves

MR Syringe: Has a single pinchable valve

Anesthesia

Local anesthesia

Sedation or paracervical block

Indications

Medical termination of pregnancy, incomplete/missed abortion, molar pregnancy, blighted ovum, endometrial sampling/biopsy.

Missed period, failed abortion, molar pregnancy, ectopic pregnancy exclusion.

questions.text: A 28 y/o woman presents with cramping and some vaginal bleeding. She is estimated to be at 8 weeks gestation based on her last menstrual period. Ultrasound confirms an intrauterine pregnancy with no fetal cardiac activity and closed cervix. Which of the following treatment regimens is most appropriate?

options.label: A
options.text: Mifepristone 200 mg orally as a single dose.

options.label: B
options.text: Mifepristone 200 mg orally followed by Misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally 24 hours later.

options.label: C
options.text: Dinoprostone 20 mg vaginal suppository every 4 hours.

questions.correct_answer: B. Mifepristone 200 mg orally followed by Misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally 24 hours later.
questions.explanation:
Trimester

Regimen

Indication

Notes

1st

Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed by Misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally after 24 hours

Medical abortion; Miscarriage.

Best method with a high success rate.
 

Mifepristone 200 mg orally alone is not effective in MTP. (Option A)

Miscarriage

Not effective

2nd

Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed by Misoprostol 400 mcg every 3 hours for up to 5 doses

MTP

Hygroscopic dilators (e.g., laminaria) may be used before administration for cervical ripening.
 

Misoprostol 400 mcg every 3 hours for up to 5 doses

MTP

Used when Mifepristone is not available.
 

Dinoprostone 20 mg vaginal every 4 hours.

(Option C)

MTP

Less commonly used.
 

High-dose intravenous Oxytocin in saline

(Option D)

MTP

Longer induction duration, hence, rarely used.

questions.text: A 28 y/o woman presents to a government-approved clinic seeking a medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). She is 8 weeks pregnant and is unmarried. She has no significant medical history and physical examination is within normal limits. According to the MTP Act, what is the most appropriate method of abortion for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Gestational Age

Abortive method

Up to 7 weeks

Medical Abortion (99% success rate if done before 7 weeks) (Option A)

Up to 9 weeks

Up to 10 weeks
  • Medical Abortion
  • Suction evacuation (Option B)

Up to 12 weeks
  • Suction evacuation
  • Dilatation and Curettage (D&C)

12-20 weeks

Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E) (Option C)

20-24 weeks
  • Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • Prostaglandin Induction.

>24 weeks

Hysterotomy (Option D)

questions.text: A 32 y/o pregnant woman at 18 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of pelvic pressure and a sensation of vaginal fullness. She denies any contractions, bleeding, or fluid leakage. Her history is significant for two previous second-trimester losses. On physical examination, her cervix appears shortened and external os is patulous. Which of the following tests helps in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Characteristics:
  • Painless dilation of the cervix in the 2nd trimester.
  • Characterized by spontaneous, painless dilation of the cervix followed by expulsion of products of conception.

Risk factors:
  • Past history of cervical surgeries such as LEEP, and conization.
  • Cervical trauma (during labour or instrumental delivery).
  • Congenital abnormality.

Diagnosis:

History of pregnancy loss in 2nd trimester:

  • TVUS- investigation of choice (Option C).
  • Normal shape and length of the cervix- T shaped and 3-4 cm.
  • Cervical length ≤2.5 cm with one 2nd trimester painless abortion, then diagnosed as cervical insufficiency.

Non-pregnant women:

If the Hegar no. 8 dilator can be passed through the internal os without any resistance.

Management:

Progesterone and cervical cerclage placement.

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman presents to her gynaecologist with a history of three consecutive first-trimester miscarriages. She and her partner are both healthy and have no significant medical history. Which of the following investigations should be done?
questions.explanation:
Type

Cause

Investigations

Endocrinopathies

Hypothyroidism

TSH

Uncontrolled DM

Blood glucose levels/ HbA1c

Luteal phase defects

Progesterone levels in 2nd half

PCOS

Pelvic USG

Uterine
  • Cervical insufficiency
  • Uterine malformations
  • Submucous fibroids
  • Asherman syndrome

Pelvic USG/ TVUS/ Hysterosalpingography

Immunological

APLA syndrome

Lupus anticoagulant

Anticardiolipin antibody

Beta2 microglobulin antibody

Chromosomal

Translocation of chromosomes

Karyotyping of both parents

questions.text: A 28 year old woman presents with heavy vaginal bleeding and severe lower abdominal pain at 14 weeks gestation. She reports passing large clots and tissue. Per speculum examination reveals an open cervix with active bleeding and presence of fetal tissue in the vagina coming out of the os. What is the most likely type of spontaneous abortion?
questions.explanation:
1)Threatened Abortion

(Option A)

Defined as bleeding through a closed cervical os in the first 20 weeks of pregnancy and with a live embryo or fetus. In this type, miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible.

2) Inevitable Abortion

(Option B)

 Either rupture of placental membranes or marked ballooning of membranes into the vagina may lead to inevitable abortion. In this type of abortion, the changes have progressed to a state where the continuation of pregnancy is impossible. There is dilated internal os and the presence of products of conception.

3) Complete Abortion

When the products of conception are expelled en masse, it is called a complete miscarriage. In complete abortion, bleeding and the internal cervical os subsequently closes over the next hour or so.

4) Missed Abortion

(Option D)

This describes dead products of conception that have been retained for days or weeks within the uterus with a closed cervical os.

5) Incomplete Abortion

(Option C)

When the entire products of conception are not expelled, instead a part of it is left inside the uterine cavity, it is called incomplete abortion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of expectant management of unruptured tubal pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: The initial beta hCG level is less than 2500 IU/L

options.label: C
options.text: Gestation sac size less than 4 cm

options.label: D
options.text: No evidence of bleeding on USG

questions.correct_answer: A. The initial beta hCG level is less than 2500 IU/L

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman’s transvaginal ultrasound reveals a 5 cm ectopic pregnancy located in the ampulla of the right fallopian tube. The initial serum beta hCG level was 3500 IU/L and has remained stable despite receiving three doses of methotrexate. What is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

A 27-year-old woman presents to the clinic with lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting. She has a history of amenorrhea for 7 weeks. On examination, she is hemodynamically stable. The physician suspects an unruptured ectopic pregnancy and advises USG evaluation with beta hCG assay. Which of the following findings is not typically seen for diagnosing an unruptured ectopic pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: Absence of intrauterine pregnancy on Transabdominal sonography with beta hCG levels ≥ 1,500 IU/L.

options.label: B
options.text: Failure to double the value of β-hCG by 48 hours along with an empty uterus

options.label: C
options.text: Adnexal mass clearly separated from the ovary

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of ring-of-fire pattern on Colour Doppler TVS

questions.correct_answer: A. Absence of intrauterine pregnancy on Transabdominal sonography with beta hCG levels ≥ 1,500 IU/L.
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Modality

Findings for Unruptured Ectopic Pregnancy

Transvaginal Sonography (TVS)
  • Absence of Intrauterine Pregnancy: No gestational sac within the uterine cavity when β-hCG ≥ 1500 IU/L.
  • Adnexal Mass: An adnexal mass clearly separate from the ovary (Blob sign). (Option C)
  • Ring-of-Fire Pattern: Increased blood flow around the ectopic mass on Color Doppler. (Option D)
  • Presence of pseudo gestational sac.
  • Free fluid in the Pouch of Douglas

Transabdominal Sonography (TAS)
  • Absence of Intrauterine Pregnancy: No gestational sac when β-hCG ≥ 6,000 IU/L
  • Other features: May be visible but less sensitive than TVS for smaller masses

Beta hCG Levels
  • Failure to double the value of β-hCG in 48 hours (Option B)
  • Lower concentration of β-hCG than expected for gestational age

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with vaginal bleeding and a positive pregnancy test. Her serum β-hCG level is 180,000 mIU/mL. Which of the following benign gestational trophoblastic diseases (GTD) is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Molar Pregnancy (Benign)

Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (Malignant)
  • Partial Mole
  • Complete Mole
  • Invasive Mole
  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor (PSTT)
  • Epithelial Trophoblastic Tumor (ETT)

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She has a positive pregnancy test. Her medical history includes a previous chlamydial infection and smoking. She also developed GDM and was preeclamptic in her last pregnancy. Which of the following is the most likely risk factor contributing to her ectopic pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Risk Factors of Ectopic Pregnancy

History of PID

History of infertility

History of tubal ligation

ART particularly if the tubes are patent but damaged

Contraception failure

Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD) use

Previous ectopic pregnancy

Previous induced abortion

Tubal reconstructive surgery

Tubal endometriosis

questions.text: Which is the most common non-tubal site for an ectopic pregnancy?

A 29-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting at 7 weeks of gestation. An ultrasound confirms an ectopic pregnancy. Which of the following statements about progesterone in ectopic pregnancy is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Progesterone levels are typically higher in ectopic pregnancies compared to normal intrauterine pregnancies.

options.label: B
options.text: Low serum progesterone levels can help differentiate between ectopic and intrauterine pregnancies.

options.label: C
options.text: Progesterone is used as a first-line treatment for ectopic pregnancies.

options.label: D
options.text: High progesterone levels are a definitive indicator of a viable intrauterine pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: B. Low serum progesterone levels can help differentiate between ectopic and intrauterine pregnancies.

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman presents with irregular vaginal bleeding 18 months after her term pregnancy. Ultrasound reveals a uterine mass, and an endometrial biopsy shows intermediate trophoblastic cells. Which of the following is NOT true regarding this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: The preferred initial treatment is chemotherapy.

options.label: D
options.text: Associated with low levels of beta-hCG.

questions.correct_answer: C. The preferred initial treatment is chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 34 y/o woman presents with persistent elevated beta-hCG levels following a molar pregnancy. Imaging studies reveal no evidence of metastases. What is the most appropriate initial chemotherapy regimen for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Risk Category

Treatment Approach

Low-Risk GTN
  • Chemotherapy: Methotrexate (MTX) alone or with folinic acid
  • Alternative Chemotherapy: Dactinomycin for MTX-resistant cases. (Option C)

High-Risk GTN
  • Chemotherapy Regimens: EMA/CO (Etoposide, Methotrexate, Actinomycin D, Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine).
  • Alternative Regimens:
    • EMA/EP (Etoposide, Methotrexate, Actinomycin D, Etoposide, Cisplatin)
    • TP/TE (Paclitaxel, Cisplatin alternating with Paclitaxel, Etoposide) (Option A)
    • BEP (Bleomycin, Etoposide, Cisplatin) (Option B)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is being assessed for gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) using the WHO Prognostic Scoring System. Which of the following factors is NOT considered in the WHO Prognostic Scoring System for GTD?
questions.correct_answer: B. Histological subtype of the tumor

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman was diagnosed with gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). Her condition is complicated by metastasis to the lungs, but no other distant sites are involved. According to the FIGO staging system, what is the appropriate stage for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Defining Criteria

Stage I

GTN is confined to the uterus. (Option A)

Stage II

GTN extends to the genital structures (e.g., vagina or pelvis) but does not spread to the lungs or other distant sites. (Option B)

Stage III

GTN has metastasized to the lungs, with or without involvement of genital structures.

Stage IV

GTN has metastasized to distant sites other than the lungs (e.g., liver, brain). (Option D)

questions.text: A 25 y/o woman presents with severe lower abdominal pain, an enlarged uterus, and elevated beta-hCG levels, suggesting molar pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. An Ultrasound finding of the ovaries is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is the tumor marker associated with choriocarcinoma?

A 25-year-old woman presents with vaginal bleeding at 12 weeks of gestation. Ultrasound shows the following appearance in the uterus. Which karyotype result is most consistent with a complete molar pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Partial Mole

Complete Mole

Karyotype

Usually 69, XXY or 69, XXX (triploid) (Option A, C)

Usually 46, XX or 46, XY (diploid)

Genetic origin

2 paternal sets + 1 maternal set

All paternal (empty egg + sperm duplication)

Fetal tissue

It may be present but abnormal.

Absent.

β-hCG levels

Elevated, but lower than the complete mole

Very high

Risk of persistent GTD

5-10%

15-20%

Risk of choriocarcinoma

2-4%

2-3%

Theca lutein cysts

Less common

Common

questions.text: Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for developing Gestational Trophoblastic Disease?
questions.correct_answer: B. Previous history of molar pregnancy
